oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Semi-weekly report on transportation orders
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Prisoners of war; Transportation, military; Refugees; Freedmen; Teachers; Missionaries; Railroads; United States -- Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen, and Abandoned Lands; Greeneville (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Semi-weekly report of the number of transportation orders received, issued, cancelled by error, and remaining on hand. It includes a statement of the amount of transportation furnished during the last half of the week ending August 26, 1865. Issued orders include numbers 5846-5951, and those remaining on hand include numbers 5852-5900. Reports include aggregate number of miles traveled by refugees, contrabands, prisoners of war, and teachers and freedmen's missionaries.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: United States -- Army -- Quartermaster's Dept.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: William Alonzo Wainwright, United States Assistant Quartermaster Records, 1861-1870
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Freedmen's missions were assembled immediately after emancipation to help elevate the education and religious awareness of recently-freed slaves. The Quartermaster of the Army provides logistical support to the combat troops in the form of ammunition, clothing, food, and pay.
